Subject: Re: [neat] Sharp Neat bugs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=5nyNBIxvLYFcMes4wdIMMfsy9asvAHh-NYrHUR8x-CbqHqrJRBth
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi again,

I'll list the fixes I've made below. These are part of
github/colgreen/SharpNEAT and also github/colgreen/UnityNEAT, with a
pull request pending to lordjesus/UnityNEAT.

I don't recall who 'lordjesus' is so I don't know whether they will
accept the request or not, but you can sync to colgreen/UnityNEAT to
get the fixes if you need to.

Fixes:

   * NeatGenome.Mutate_AddConnection() #1 - Selecting source neuron index.
   * NeatGenome.Mutate_AddConnection() #2 - Selecting target neuron index.
   * NeatGenome.Mutate_ConnectionWeights() - Improved :)
   * NeatEvolutionAlgorithm.CalcSpecieStats() #1 & #2. Both addressed
by using a 'perfectly' unstable sort (i.e. equal items are randomly
distributed amongst themselves).

I think the AddConnection() bugs were the most significant and likely
affect the quality of evolved networks.

The CalcSpecieStats() fix/enhancement might improve genetic diversity
in some circumstances, especially when the fitness is flat for a
number of generations. It's hard to say how much of an effect that
would have to NEAT overall, maybe not much or maybe a lot.

The Mutate_ConnectionWeights() was more of a design choice. If a
network is approaching having all of it's connections mutated then
it's either very small or the mutation proportion number has been
configured to be very high, which probabyl isn't going to be useful.
But you're right in saying that it should be known that there are
caveats, if e.g. someone were experimenting with these settings and
drawing conclusions.

Cheers, and thanks for taking the time to read through the code!

 - Colin
